channel.title: NYT > Movies

item.title: Best Movies of 2025
item.description: Our film critics rank their 10 favorites of the year.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Put Your Soul on Your Hand and Walk (Movie)

item.title: With ‘Five Nights at Freddy’s 2’ and ‘I Love L.A.,’ Josh Hutcherson Is Back
item.description: The “Five Nights at Freddy’s” and “I Love L.A.” star found instant success as a child actor. After his “Hunger Games” fame, it felt like it almost all went away.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: “As a kid, I never wanted to leave set,” Hutcherson said about his early acting years.

item.title: ‘Jay Kelly’ Review: All His Memories Are Movies
item.description: Noah Baumbach’s latest film has George Clooney playing the last of the old-school movie stars.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: But Who Is the Snake in ‘Zootopia 2’?
item.description: Gary Goldman, who has battled Disney in court over the franchise, thinks the viper Gary De’Snake is based on him.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes

item.title: What ‘Hamnet’ Lost (and Gained) on the Way From Page to Screen
item.description: The filmmaker Chloé Zhao and the novelist-turned-screenwriter Maggie O’Farrell explained the changes they made in the tale of Shakespeare, his wife and their son.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: 20 Holiday Romance Movies to Stream Now: ‘Love Actually,’ ‘Serendipity’ and More
item.description: From timeless classics to frothy distractions, we’ve picked the best holiday romances currently available to stream.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer

item.title: ‘Little Trouble Girls’ Review: Teenage Infatuation
item.description: Despite awareness of taboos, two girls in a Catholic school choir are drawn to each other in this feature debut by the Slovenian director Urska Djukic.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: 11 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: ‘WTO/99’ Review: The ‘Battle in Seattle’ as Seen by the Participants
item.description: To tell the story of the demonstrations surrounding a World Trade Organization meeting, “WTO/99” assembled scenes shot by the participants themselves.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: From Improv Class to Mayor-Elect: Zohran Mamdani’s Cultural Influences
item.description: In an interview, he revealed the Indian ragas, indie movies, comedy shows and museums in the city that stayed with him.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Graham Dickie for The New York Times
item.media:description: In some ways, Zohran Mamdani’s cultural influences would be familiar to any New York City kid.

item.title: Cynthia Erivo on Her Favorite Books, “Wicked” and Her New Memoir
item.description: “I have to be still for a certain amount of time,” says the “Wicked” star and author of “Simply More: A Book for Anyone Who Has Been Told They’re Too Much.”
item.category: Simply More: A Book for Anyone Who Has Been Told They're Too Much (Book)

item.title: Francis Ford Coppola’s F.P. Journe Sells for $11 Million at Auction
item.description: Frenzied bidding pushed the polarizing F.P. Journe timepiece into near-record territory despite one dealer calling the design “goofy.”
item.dc:creator: Jacob Bernstein

item.title: Kristen Stewart Wants to Blow Up the Myth of the Brilliant Male Actor
item.description: The actress and director says the world of filmmaking needs a “full system break.”
item.dc:creator: David Marchese
item.media:credit: Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times

item.title: The Area 51 of New England
item.description: Through trinkets and tales, a U.F.O. story that once captured national attention lives on.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi and John Tully

item.title: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s movies include cosmopolitan assassins, flesh-slicing swashbucklers and seasoned supernatural detectives.
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg

item.title: Fans Are Obsessed With This Celebrity Couple. They Star in ‘Zootopia.’
item.description: WildeHopps, a.k.a. the fox and bunny at the heart of the franchise, has inspired a YouTube movie, TikToks, fancams and more. The obsession goes deep (and sometimes weird).
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:description: Nick Wilde (voiced by Jason Bateman) and Judy Hopps (Ginnifer Goodwin) in “Zootopia 2.”

item.title: After ‘Working Girl,’ Can Christopher Ashley Bring His Sunshine to New York?
item.description: Before returning to New York to lead Roundabout, Christopher Ashley is concluding his 18-year tenure at La Jolla Playhouse with the new musical “Working Girl.”
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times
item.media:description: He’s got the magic touch: Twenty shows that La Jolla Playhouse helped to develop during Christopher Ashley’s tenure have made their way to Broadway.

item.title: Dashing Through a Season of Holiday Movies
item.description: For one writer, putting together her annual roundup of streaming holiday movies requires open-mindedness — and a high tolerance for candy-coated clichés.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, ‘Mortal Kombat’ Actor, Dies at 75
item.description: The actor, born in Japan, starred in dozens of film and television shows, including Amazon’s “The Man in the High Castle.” His career spanned more than three decades.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman

item.title: Netflix to Buy Warner Bros in $83 Billion Deal
item.description: The deal to acquire the Hollywood behemoth’s television and film studios as well as HBO Max will bulk up the world’s biggest paid streaming service.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes, Lauren Hirsch and Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Netflix has never tried an acquisition even remotely close to this size.

item.title: ‘Five Nights at Freddy’s 2’ Review: The Robots Are Malfunctioning (Again)
item.description: The bigger-budget follow-up to last year’s abysmal cult horror hit about haunted animatronic puppets is, at best, marginally scarier.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘La Grazia’ Review: Paolo Sorrentino’s Portrait of Waning Power
item.description: The director reunites with Toni Servillo, casting the astonishingly expressive actor as a fictional Italian president facing the end of his term.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Merrily We Roll Along’ Review: It’s a Hit (Reprise)
item.description: The Tony-winning Broadway revival of the notorious Stephen Sondheim flop, starring Jonathan Groff, Daniel Radcliffe and Lindsay Mendez, gets a live stage recording for the big screen.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.media:description: From left, Daniel Radcliffe, Jonathan Groff and Lindsay Mendez in “Merrily We Roll Along.”

item.title: ‘Rosemead’ Review: A Mother and Her Troubled Son
item.description: In this drama, Lucy Liu offers a compassionate and grim portrait of a parent at the end of her rope.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: ‘Happy Holidays’ Review: Fissures in a Palestinian Family
item.description: In Scandar Copti’s film, set in Haifa, Israel, secrets and deceptions strain relationships.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Fackham Hall’ Review: Keep Calm and Chuckle On
item.description: Clever sight gags jazz up this “Downton Abbey” sendup about a bookish aristocrat under pressure to marry her first cousin.
item.dc:creator: Natalia Winkelman

item.title: ‘Endless Cookie’ Review: An Animated Family History
item.description: Two filmmaking brothers trade tales in a tonally singular documentary.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: ‘The Chronology of Water’ Review: Saved by the Pen
item.description: Kristen Stewart’s feature directing debut stars a riveting Imogen Poots in an uncomfortably visceral tale of abuse and addiction.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: ‘100 Nights of Hero’ Review: A Feminist Fairy Tale
item.description: This flawed but endearing film stars Emma Corrin as a protective maid and features Charli XCX as a sister with a secret.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: ‘Oh. What. Fun.,’ ‘My Secret Santa’ and More Christmas Movies to Stream
item.description: From “Oh. What. Fun.” to “A Very Jonas Christmas Movie,” a roundup of several new holiday titles to stream this season.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: Which Films Could Be Nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars?
item.description: “One Battle After Another,” “Sinners,” “Hamnet,” “Marty Supreme” and “Sentimental Value” are almost certain to be nominated. After that, it’s anyone’s guess.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Sondheim’s ‘Merrily We Roll Along’ Is Now a Film. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The Broadway revival, starring Daniel Radcliffe, Jonathan Groff and Lindsay Mendez, was transformative. Here’s what to know about the show, and the movie.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jonathan Groff, with Daniel Radcliffe and other cast members, at the “Merrily We Roll Along” taping in 2024.

item.title: See All the Stars at the Gotham Awards: Elle Fanning, Hugh Jackman and More
item.description: It was all roast beef, chocolate cake and air kisses at the Gotham Awards in Lower Manhattan.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr and Rebecca Smeyne
item.media:credit: Rebecca Smeyne for The New York Times

item.title: Why Are There So Many Films Right Now Based on the Bible?
item.description: Films that take their stories from the Old or New Testament are filling screens big and small. To understand why, it helps to know Hollywood history.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.media:description: Nicolas Cage as Joseph in “The Carpenter’s Son,” one of a host of recent and forthcoming movies based on biblical stories.

item.title: Is Gen X Actually the Greatest Generation?
item.description: How one era changed everything about the culture — and why we’re so nostalgic for its creations.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Fortini and Neal Slavin

item.title: Jafar Panahi, Who Filmed in Secret in Iran, Wins Big at Gotham Awards
item.description: He won best director, original screenplay and international feature for “It Was Just an Accident.” Best feature went to “One Battle After Another.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:description: Jafar Panahi at the Gothams on Monday.

item.title: ‘The Merchants of Joy’ Review: Cutthroat Christmas Tree Sales
item.description: A new documentary contains zesty character studies of competing New York City tree vendors as they prepare for the holiday season.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: Best Movies and Shows Streaming in December 2025
item.description: “F1: The Movie,” “It’s Never Over, Jeff Buckley” and “The Life of Chuck” arrive, and “Fallout” and “Percy Jackson” return.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray
item.category: Percy Jackson and the Olympians (TV Program)

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix in December
item.description: A slew of new titles are coming this month, including the latest “Knives Out” mystery and a film starring George Clooney and Adam Sandler.
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: Nathan Lane and Laurie Metcalf to Star in ‘Death of a Salesman’ on Broadway
item.description: Joe Mantello will direct the next revival of Arthur Miller’s “Death of a Salesman,” opening in April at the Winter Garden Theater.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: CJ Rivera/Invision, via Associated Press, Rob Grabowski/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nathan Lane, who was last on Broadway in 2023, and Laurie Metcalf, who is currently in the Broadway production of “Little Bear Ridge Road,” will star opposite each other as Willy and Linda Loman.
